DOC.brief_summary: WHO recommends to take TB drugs while fasting: if TB drugs are taken with food, perhaps drug concentrations are too low; on the other hand: if this is not tolerated, drugs could also be taken with food. Do lower drug concentrations - with improved adherence to therapy - outweigh the disadvantage of lower drug blood concentrations over time? How exactly do the drug concentrations over time (pharmacokinetics) compare between fasting and fed conditions, especially in the early stage of TB treatment when patients are relatively sick, and relatively poorly tolerate TB drugs?
DOC.brief_title: HRZE Fasted/Fed in Newly Diagnosed TB
DOC.detailed_description: To evaluate the influence of concomitant food ingestion on the pharmacokinetics of HRZE in newly diagnosed TB patients To evaluate the influence of early disease on the PK parameters of HRZE in TB patients To compare the pharmacokinetics of HRZE in the early stage of disease with the pharmacokinetics of HRZE in more stable condition in newly diagnosed TB patients To evaluate adverse events of HRZE in TB patients
DOC.criteria: Patients with TB who are starting with HRZE therapy Age > 18 years old Written informed consent Use of antacids, which cannot be discontinued for study days Active, unstable hepatic disease (with jaundice, HRZ)
